text: Barnes is a city in Washington County, Kansas, United States. In 2020, 165 people lived there. ==History== Barnes was called Elm Grove when it was created in 1870. It was renamed Barnes in 1876. It was named after A. S. Barnes, a stockholder of the Central Branch Union Pacific Railroad. Barnes was a station and shipping place on the Missouri Pacific Railroad. ==Geography== Barnes is at (39.711525, -96.873094). The United States Census Bureau says that the city has a total area of . Of that, is land and is water. ==People== ===2020 census=== The 2020 census says that there were 165 people, 72 households, and 48 families living in Barnes. Of the households, 77.8% owned their home and 22.2% rented their home. The median age was 45.2 years. Of the people, 87.9% were White, 2.4% were from some other race, and 9.7% were two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 15.2% of the people. ===2010 census=== The 2010 census says that there were 159 people, 71 households, and 45 families living in Barnes. ==Education== Barnes is a part of USD 223 Barnes Hanover Linn. Barnes schools were closed in 1965 because of school unification. The Barnes High School mascot was the Bullets."Barnes Wins Washington Meet", The Belleville Telescope, 20 February 1941, p.8. ==Famous people== * Omar Knedlik, (1915â€“1989), inventor of the ICEE frozen drink. ==References== ==Other websites== ;City * City of Barnes * Barnes - Directory of Public Officials ;Schools * USD 223, local school district ;Maps * Barnes City Map , KDOT Category:Cities in Washington County, Kansas Category:1870 establishments in Kansas
title: Barnes, Kansas
